title: league of legends is classic
body: i started playing that game in the beginning of season 4 . the developers care only about diamond and above rank  . they nerf  champions that win a lot on high elo . we can say that high elo have more experience  and they know how to play so the developers nerf and buff champions according to high elo . but i dont know why the developers refuse to do something that fans of lol want . i have no idea why the developers removed rotating game mode . and i also dont know why these game modes are not permanent . i feel like the developers want people to play normal mode summoner rift or quit the game . i dont think that will make riot lose alot or cause an error . i dont have fun any more playing  summoner rift  . and soon i will get bored from aram . if urf is a permanent mode i would spend more than  20 % of my day playing it

replies.body:
>i also dont know why these game modes are not permanent 

They aren't permanent because there's not enough continuous demand for them to justify a permanent queue. There would be so few people at any given time that either matchmaking would be so off that challengers would be matched with unrankeds or hour-long waiting times for a game. By limiting their availability to only a few weekends per year they are able to keep them fresh and people's interests enough to have a healthy playerbase when they are available.

then may  you please tell me why aram is permanent  ?? if you are going to answer cause many people playing it  more than x10 people who is playing aram play other modes when they come out  . and i dont think if the mode is permanent it will be ugly
The reason that so many people play the other modes is exactly because they're temporary. If they were permanent modes the novelty would wear out fast and they'd get stagnant like Dominion was.

As a side note, Dominion is a terrible example to use here because the situation was much more nuanced than simply "the novelty wore out." The average League player wasn't interested due to the negative perception (and common misconceptions) of the mode. Meanwhile, Dom fans lost interest due to Riot not following through on promises of support and competitive features.

Snowdown Showdown, Legend of the Poro King, or even URF would've been better examples.
